newsitem.title: NEW ZEALAND: CRICKET-NZ CRUSHES SRI LANKA BY AN INNINGS.
newsitem.headline: CRICKET-NZ CRUSHES SRI LANKA BY AN INNINGS.

text.p: A blazing run-a-ball century from wicketkeeper Romesh Kaluwitharana failed to save Sri Lanka from an innings defeat in the first test in New Zealand on Monday.
New Zealand, back to winning ways after a 2-0 home series loss to England, take an unbeatable 1-0 lead in the two-match series into the next test starting in Hamilton on Friday.
Sri Lanka started the day in the hopeless position of 37 without loss after being forced to follow on 364 behind.
But the tourists showed defiance, first through a well-compiled 50 by Sanath Jayasuriya and later in a fighting century stand between Kaluwitharana and Chaminda Vaas.
They finally surrendered with the total on 328, shortly before the scheduled close of play on the fourth day.
Kaluwitharana came to the crease with Sri Lanka at 115 for five and proceeded to smash the Kiwi attack to all corners in reaching 103.
His scintillating 137 run partnership with Vaas ended when he offered a low, hard return catch to teenage left arm spinner Daniel Vettori.
The century included 13 fours and two sixes and was his second in tests.
For New Zealand the test was a welcome reversal of form.

The team went into the match in some disarray, having lost to a mediocre England side and failed to win a test at home in three years. Lee Germon was dumped as skipper last week in favour of 23-year old Stephen Fleming, the youngest captain in the country's history.
New Zealand were further hit by the late withdrawal of fast bowler Geoff Allott just before the test began, but proceeded to dominate every session of the test.

Victory was built around a superb unbeaten 267 by man-of-the-match Bryan Young. It was the second highest test innings by a New Zealander after Martin Crowe's 299, also against Sri Lanka six years ago.

Sri Lanka's hopes of saving the game with a big second innings were dealt a series of blows in the morning session when they lost openers Roshan Mahanama for 21, Jayasuriya for 50, dangerman Aravinda de Silva for nought and Marvan Atapattu for 22.
While Sri Lanka had more than their share of misfortune in the match, the New Zealanders made their own luck with some brilliant fielding.

Arjuna Ranatunga went to a stupendous catch by Matt Horne at mid-wicket on 13. The Sri Lanakan captain tried to hit left-arm spinner Daniel Vettori over Horne but the fielder showed great athleticism to leap high and snare the ball in his right hand.
Hashan Tillekaratne was out 18 runs later as Sri Lanka slumped to 133 for six when he was run out to a brilliant piece of fielding by 12th man Chris Harris.
All the bowlers contributed equally but most penetrating was Simon Doull, who added to his five wicket first innings bag with three for 82.
